verses.text: In those days, Mattathias son of John, son of Simeon, a priest of the family of Joarib, left Jerusalem and settled in Modein.
verses.comment: Mattathias is identified as a priest descended from Joarib, one of the priestly families. His lineage establishes the legitimate priestly authority. The flight to Modein sets the stage for his key role in the coming revolt.

verses.text: He had five sons: John called Gaddi,
verses.comment: The naming and numbering of Mattathias' sons is important for the continuation of the movement and the establishment of leadership.

verses.text: Simon called Thassi;
verses.comment: Simon would later become the leader of the revolt and high priest, reinforcing the enduring importance of apostolic succession in leadership.

verses.text: Judas called Maccabeus;
verses.comment: Judas Maccabeus would become the chief commander of the revolt. The nickname 'Maccabeus' possibly means 'hammer', symbolizing his strength.

verses.text: Eleazar called Avaran, and Jonathan called Apphus.
verses.comment: The five sons would each play their roles in the struggle for religious fidelity and national freedom.

verses.text: When he saw the blasphemies being committed in Judah and Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Mattathias's outrage over blasphemy echoes the deep call for purity of worship and the defense of the faith.

verses.text: he said, 'Alas! Why was I born to see the ruin of my people and the destruction of the holy city, to dwell there when it has been given into the hands of the enemy, and the sanctuary into the hands of foreigners?
verses.comment: Lament over the desecration of Jerusalem and its temple recalls previous times of destruction, with a heart yearning for restoration.

verses.text: Her temple has become like a man without honor.
verses.comment: The comparison highlights the sacredness of the temple and the shame of its profanation, pointing to the deep reverence for places of worship.

verses.text: Her glorious vessels have been carried off into exile.
verses.comment: The loss of sacred vessels parallels earlier times of exile and foreshadows the restoration hopes seen throughout Israelite history.

verses.text: Her children have been slaughtered in her streets, her young men by the enemy’s sword.
verses.comment: The lament develops the theme of innocent blood and martyrdom, resonant with later Christian understandings about suffering for the faith.

verses.text: What nation has not claimed her as spoil, and what people has not taken her possessions?
verses.comment: Israel’s suffering is universal, showing the ongoing struggle between the people of God and the world.

verses.text: All her adornment has been taken away. She, free, has become a slave.
verses.comment: Israel once glorified, now enslaved—a motif of divine reversal and hope for redemption reminiscent of Christ’s own humility (Phil. 2:7).

verses.text: Behold, our holy things, our beauty, and our glory have been laid waste. The Gentiles have profaned them.
verses.comment: The desecration by Gentiles is highlighted—a recurring theme pointing to the need for steadfastness and unity in preserving what is holy.

verses.text: Why should we live any longer?
verses.comment: A cry of despair, yet also a call to action. The question leads to the decision to resist and preserve the faith.

verses.text: Then Mattathias and his sons tore their clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourned deeply.
verses.comment: The gestures of mourning mirror ancient practices for expressing grief over sin and desecration—preparing for repentance and renewal.

verses.text: The officers of the king who were enforcing apostasy came to Modein to make the people sacrifice.
verses.comment: The king’s officials’ arrival to compel idolatry marks a central conflict: the forces of political power seeking to overturn true worship.

verses.text: Many in Israel agreed with them, forsaking the law and the covenants, and joining with them.
verses.comment: Some Israelites choose compromise, showing the temptation to conform rather than preserve the faith—similar to challenges Christians face today.

verses.text: And the men of Modein and Mattathias were invited to make sacrifice.
verses.comment: The personal challenge to Mattathias reveals a test of leadership—whether to betray the law or stand firm for true worship.

verses.text: Then the king’s officer said to Mattathias, 'You are a leader, honored and great in this city, and supported by sons and brothers.
verses.comment: Mattathias is recognized as a leader, targeted for influence; this displays the impact faithful leadership can have in guiding God’s people.

verses.text: So come forward first and fulfill the king’s command, as all the nations and the Israelites in Judah and those left in Jerusalem have done. Then you and your sons will be numbered among the king’s friends, and you and your sons will be honored with silver, gold, and many gifts.'
verses.comment: The offer of bribes echoes other biblical tests, where compromise is rewarded materially. It underscores the lure of worldly honors contrasted against the call to remain faithful.

verses.text: But Mattathias answered with a loud voice, 'Even if all the nations obey the king, yielding to his command, forsaking the law and the commands of our ancestors,
verses.comment: Mattathias’s resolute response parallels the bravery of Daniel’s friends in Babylon, emphasizing fidelity to God above all else.

verses.text: I and my sons and my brothers will live by the covenant of our ancestors.
verses.comment: His declaration highlights covenant faithfulness and family continuity—themes later connected to the idea of apostolic tradition safeguarding doctrine.

verses.text: Far be it from us to forsake the law and ordinances.
verses.comment: A firm stand for the divine law, anticipating the call to uphold all that God has instituted for His people’s salvation.

verses.text: We will not obey the king’s command by turning aside from our worship, either to the right hand or to the left.'
verses.comment: Refusal to deviate from true worship is reminiscent of Israel’s call to keep the law without compromise, a foundational concept in Christian discipleship.

verses.text: When he had finished speaking, a Jew came forward in the sight of all to offer sacrifice on the altar in Modein according to the king’s decree.
verses.comment: The public apostasy is a critical turning point: the visible breach of fidelity elicits a decisive response.

verses.text: When Mattathias saw it, he was filled with zeal, and his heart was moved. He gave a righteous anger, ran up, and killed him on the altar.
verses.comment: Like Phinehas in Numbers 25, Mattathias’s zeal foreshadows Christ overturning the money changers’ tables (John 2:15)—righteous anger in defense of true worship.

verses.text: He also killed the king’s officer who wanted to compel them to sacrifice, and he tore down the altar.
verses.comment: Mattathias acts as a reformer, eradicating false worship and purifying the community—anticipating acts of reform in later church history.

verses.text: With zeal for the law, Mattathias cried out through the city, 'Let everyone who is zealous for the law and upholds the covenant follow me!'
verses.comment: Mattathias’s call gathers the faithful, paralleling later calls for unity and faithfulness under God’s authority.

verses.text: He and his sons fled to the mountains, leaving behind all they had.
verses.comment: The faithful remnant retreats, echoing Christ’s teaching about forsaking worldly possessions (Matt. 19:29).

verses.text: Then many who sought justice and righteousness went down into the wilderness to settle there,
verses.comment: The withdrawal into the wilderness recalls patterns of spiritual renewal and preparation seen in biblical tradition, including John the Baptist.

verses.text: along with their children, wives, and livestock, because calamities pressed them so severely.
verses.comment: Their suffering is depicted as total. Commitment involves sacrifice not only of self but of family, pointing ahead to teaching about Christian discipleship.

verses.text: It was reported to the king’s officers and the troops in Jerusalem, the city of David, that those who defied the king’s commands had gone down to hide in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Resistance is noted by the authorities, cementing the remnant's role as the true defenders of the faith.

verses.text: Many went in pursuit of them, and, overtaking them, they camped opposite and made preparations to attack them on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: The decision to attack on the Sabbath exploits the sabbath-keepers' fidelity, raising theological questions about law and mercy.

verses.text: They said to them, 'Enough! Come out and obey the king’s order, and you will live.'
verses.comment: The persecutors offer supposed mercy but at the cost of obedience to men over God, articulating the sharp line of resistance for the faithful.

verses.text: But they replied, 'We will not come out or obey the king’s command, profaning the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: Steadfastness not to profane holy things sets a model for Christian integrity.

verses.text: Then they hurried to attack them on the Sabbath, and they killed them, their wives, their children, and their livestock—about a thousand people.
verses.comment: Martyrdom for the sake of the law is a recurring theme, with many later martyrs following this example. The number echoes completeness—a whole remnant giving their lives.

verses.text: When Mattathias and his friends heard what had happened to them, they mourned greatly.
verses.comment: Sorrow for those who died reflects communal intercession—similar to Christian prayers for the faithful departed.

verses.text: They said to one another, 'If we all do as our brothers have done and refuse to fight on the Sabbath and holy days, they will quickly destroy us from the earth.'
verses.comment: Reflection on the law’s intent versus its application foreshadows Christ teaching about mercy above sacrifice.

verses.text: So that day they resolved: 'If anyone comes to attack us on the Sabbath, we will fight and not all die, as our brothers did in the hiding places.'
verses.comment: The adaptation of Sabbath observance under necessity illustrates the priority of life, in harmony with Christ’s teachings.

verses.text: Then joined them a group of Hasideans, mighty warriors of Israel, every one devoted to the law.
verses.comment: Those zealous for the law join the resistance—a forerunner of later orders and movements focused on holiness and defending orthodoxy.

verses.text: All those escaping the peril joined forces with them and supported them.
verses.comment: Unity and support among the faithful mirror the importance of the church’s visible fellowship and communal prayer.

verses.text: They organized an army and struck down sinners in their anger and apostates in their wrath; the survivors fled before them.
verses.comment: Purification of the community anticipates future teachings about church discipline and perseverance in holiness.

verses.text: Mattathias and his friends went about tearing down altars;
verses.comment: Active reform—destroying false altars—connects to reform movements and the importance of right worship.

verses.text: they forcibly circumcised all the uncircumcised children they found within the borders of Israel.
verses.comment: The restoration of covenant sign points to the necessity of sacramental signs for membership in the people of God.

verses.text: They vigorously pursued the arrogant men, and work prospered in their hands.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and courage bring blessing; this pattern appears repeatedly throughout Scripture.

verses.text: They rescued the law out of the hands of the Gentiles and of kings, and they did not allow the sinner to triumph.
verses.comment: The law as a treasure entrusted to a faithful remnant recalls stewardship of the faith and non-compromise in times of trial.

verses.text: When the days drew near for Mattathias to die, he said to his sons:
verses.comment: Like Jacob, Mattathias gathers his sons for a last testament—passing on faith and leadership, a foundational pattern for apostolic succession.

verses.text: 'Now arrogance and reproach have grown stronger; it is a time of destruction and furious anger.
verses.comment: The circumstances are dire, echoing Old Testament themes of judgment and the need for redemption.

verses.text: Now, my children, be zealous for the law and give your lives for the covenant of your ancestors.
verses.comment: Exhortation to martyrdom prefigures Christian teaching about taking up one's cross and being willing to die for the faith (Mark 8:34).

verses.text: Remember the deeds of our fathers, which they did in their own generations; and you shall receive great honor and an everlasting name.
verses.comment: Endurance in faith leads to lasting honor and eternal remembrance. Reflects Christ's call to share in His glory through faithful witness.

verses.text: Was not Abraham found faithful when tested, and it was counted to him as righteousness?
verses.comment: Abraham’s faith is cited as the model—faith and works cooperate in God’s plan for salvation.

verses.text: Joseph in the time of his distress kept the commandment and became ruler of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph’s perseverance in virtue despite suffering is an example of faith under trial.

verses.text: Phinehas our father, because he was zealous, received the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.
verses.comment: Zeal leads to spiritual blessing; the everlasting priesthood points to the importance of ordained ministry succeeded through generations.

verses.text: Joshua, because he fulfilled the word, became a judge in Israel.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and obedience raise leaders up; later mirrored in Christian service and leadership.

verses.text: Caleb, for bearing witness before the congregation, received an inheritance in the land.
verses.comment: Bearing witness leads to reward and lasting heritage, a concept affirmed by Christ’s promises for faithful testimony.

verses.text: David, for being obedient, inherited the throne of a kingdom forever.
verses.comment: David’s eternal throne prefigures Christ’s kingship and rules by the promises given to him, as fulfilled in the New Testament.

verses.text: Elijah, for his zeal for the law, was taken up into heaven.
verses.comment: Elijah’s assumption is a testimony of special grace for zeal, connecting to later Christian belief in bodily resurrection and the reward of saints.

verses.text: Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael, for their faith, were saved from the fire.
verses.comment: Salvation from danger for their steadfast faith parallels salvation through steadfastness in Christ.

verses.text: Daniel, for his innocence, was delivered from the mouth of lions.
verses.comment: Deliverance for innocence and faithfulness foreshadows Christ’s resurrection as proof of His innocence and victory over death.

verses.text: Observe from generation to generation that all those who hope in Him will not fail.
verses.comment: Enduring hope and fidelity are key for blessing and salvation, reflecting the faith of the communion of saints.

verses.text: Do not be afraid of the words of a sinful man, for his glory will end in rot and worms.
verses.comment: Worldly power is fleeting, but divine glory endures. Encourages believers to prefer eternal values to temporal power.

verses.text: Today he is exalted, tomorrow he is gone; he will return to dust, and his plans will vanish.
verses.comment: A meditation on the transience of human greatness, contrasting it with the endurance of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Children, be courageous and strong in the law, for in it you will find glory.
verses.comment: Final charge to courage and fidelity ties strength to the law—prefiguring Christ’s command to keep His commandments for glory.

verses.text: Behold, I know that your brother Simon is a man of wisdom; listen to him always; he shall be father to you.
verses.comment: The appointment of Simon as spiritual head echoes biblical patterns of succession and authority among the apostles and the Church.

verses.text: Judas Maccabeus, strong and mighty from his youth, he shall be your commander and lead you in battle.
verses.comment: Judas’s appointment shows the value of orderly leadership and strong defense of the truth.

verses.text: Gather around you all who observe the law, and avenge the wrongs of your people.
verses.comment: Collective action by the faithful to defend truth prefigures many later calls to defend the faith and right worship.

verses.text: Repay the Gentiles, and obey the commandments of the law.
verses.comment: Obedience and holy zeal; justice and loyalty to the law are intertwined—suggesting the call to both action and fidelity in Christian life.

verses.text: He blessed them, and was gathered to his ancestors.
verses.comment: The passing of the patriarch with a blessing points to the biblical tradition of giving a final blessing, seen in later generations.

verses.text: He died in the one hundred and forty-sixth year and was buried in the tomb of his fathers at Modein, and all Israel mourned him with great lamentation.
verses.comment: The burial and national mourning show the deep respect for those who defend the faith, a foreshadowing of honoring saints and martyrs.

verses.text: Thus ended the life of Mattathias.
verses.comment: Mattathias's death closes the chapter, marking the transition of leadership and the continuing struggle, with hope passed on to the next generation.
